   &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;653,900&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;$&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;$&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;1,083,600&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair&#13;Value of Asset Retirement Obligation&lt;/i&gt; &amp;#150; &lt;/b&gt;The Deer Creek asset retirement obligation is the estimated cost to close&#13;the Deer Creek facility under terms of the lease, meeting environmental and State of Colorado regulatory requirements. The estimate&#13;is determined at discrete points in time based upon significant unobservable inputs in which little or no market activity exists&#13;that is significant to the fair value of the liability, therefore requiring the Company to develop its own assumptions. Management&amp;#146;s&#13;estimate of the asset retirement obligation is based upon a cost estimate developed by a consultant knowledgeable of government&#13;closure requirements and costs incurred at similar water disposal facility operations. The process used was to identify each activity&#13;in the closure process, obtain vendor estimated costs, in current dollars, to perform the closure activity and accumulating the&#13;various vendor estimates to determine the asset retirement obligation. A present value discount has not been taken as the estimated&#13;closure costs, excluding regulatory changes and inflation adjustments, are anticipated to remain fairly consistent over the operational&#13;life of the facility. The lack of an active market to validate the estimated asset retirement obligation results in the fair value&#13;of asset retirement obligation to be a Level 3 fair value measurement. ASC Topic 410-20: Asset Retirement Obligations requires&#13;the Company to review the asset retirement obligation on a recurring basis and record changes in the period incurred.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Fair Value of Contingent Payments&#13;&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&amp;#150; The contingent land payment liability is also determined at discrete points in time based upon unobservable inputs&#13;in which little or no market activity exists that is significant to the fair value of the liability, therefore requiring the Company&#13;to develop its own assumptions. In calculating the estimate of fair value for the contingent land payment, management completed&#13;an estimate of the present value of the contingent liability based upon projected income, cash flows and capital expenditures for&#13;the Deer Creek facility developed under plans currently approved by the Company&amp;#146;s board of directors. Different assumptions&#13;relative to the expansion or alternative uses of the Deer Creek and Indian Mesa facilities could result in significantly different&#13;valuations. The projected payments have been discounted at a rate of 3% per annum to determine net present value. The lack of an&#13;active market to validate the estimated contingent land liability results in the fair value of the contingent land liability to&#13;be a Level 3 fair value measurement. ASC Topic 820: Fair Value Measurement requires the Company to review the contingent land liability&#13;on a recurring basis and record changes in the period incurred.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Fair Value of Financial Instruments&lt;/b&gt;&#13;&amp;#150; The Company&amp;#146;s financial instruments consist of cash and cash equivalents, accounts receivable, note receivable, trust&#13;account, accounts payable, accrued liabilities and note payable. The fair value of these financial instruments approximates their&#13;carrying values using Level 3 inputs, based on their short maturities or for long-term debt, based on borrowing rates currently&#13;available to us for loans with similar terms and maturities.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Land, Property and Equipment&lt;/b&gt;&#13;&amp;#150; Land, Property and Equipment are stated at cost. Depreciation is computed over the estimated useful lives of the assets&#13;using the straight-line method, generally over a 3 to 20 year period. Currently all office furniture and equipment are being depreciated&#13;over 3 years; production equipment over 7 to 10 years; and the water disposal facility over 15 to 20 years including 15 years for&#13;the evaporation pond liners and 20 years for the pond construction costs. Expenditures for ordinary maintenance and repairs are&#13;charged to expense as incurred while betterments or renewals are capitalized. Upon retirement or disposal of assets, the cost and&#13;accumulated depreciation are eliminated from the account and any gain or loss is reflected in the statement of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Assets Held for Sale&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150;&#13;The Company has implemented a plan to divest its 160 acre owned and undeveloped land and associated permits located in Whitewater,&#13;Colorado and known as Indian Mesa. As a result, the cost of the land and associated permits has been reclassified as Assets Held&#13;for Sale at June 30, 2016. A long-lived asset classified as held for sale shall be measured at the lower of its carrying amount&#13;or fair value less cost to sell. The value of Assets Held for Sale represents the carrying amount.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Trust Account &amp;#150; Asset Retirement&#13;Obligation&lt;/b&gt; &amp;#150; The Company is required to make quarterly payments to a trust account for the closure costs of the Deer&#13;Creek facility. The Company reflects the gross amount of the trust as an asset and the gross amount of the estimated closure cost&#13;as a liability.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Income Taxes&lt;/b&gt; - The Company accounts&#13;for income taxes under the asset and liability method, which requires recognition of deferred tax assets and liabilities for the&#13;expected future tax consequences of events that have been included in the financial statements or tax returns. Under this method,&#13;deferred tax assets and liabilities are determined based on the difference between the financial statement basis and tax basis&#13;of assets and liabilities using enacted tax rates in effect for the year in which the differences are expected to reverse. To the&#13;extent that the Company does not consider it more likely than not that a future tax asset will be recovered, it provides a valuation&#13;allowance against the excess. If the Company had an income tax obligation and if any interest or penalties were assessed related&#13;to an underpayment, the Company would recognize the interest or penalty due by charging any penalty to other operating expense&#13;and any interest to interest expense in the period that they are assessed.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Use of Estimates&lt;/b&gt; - The preparation&#13;of the Company's consolidated financial statements in conformity with accounting principles generally accepted in the United States&#13;of America requires the Company's management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the amounts reported in these consolidated&#13;financial statements and accompanying notes. Actual results could differ from those estimates.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company makes significant estimates&#13;and assumptions concerning the estimated fair value of stock-based compensation and detachable warrants, realization of deferred&#13;tax assets, collectability of accounts and note receivable, estimated useful lives and carrying values of fixed assets, the recorded&#13;values of accruals and contingencies including the Black Creek contingent liability and the estimated fair values of the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;asset retirement obligation and the contingent land and purchase price liabilities, and the Company&amp;#146;s ability to continue&#13;as a going concern. Due to the uncertainties inherent in the estimation process and the significance of these items, it is at least&#13;reasonably possible that the estimates in connection with these items could be materially revised within the next year.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Impairment of Long-Lived Assets&lt;/b&gt;&#13;- The Company&amp;#146;s policy is to perform an assessment for impairment whenever events or changes in circumstances indicate that&#13;the carrying amount of a long-lived asset may not be recoverable. If the net carrying value of the asset exceeds estimated future&#13;undiscounted net cash flows, then an impairment is recognized to reduce the carrying value to the estimated fair value. No impairment&#13;charge was recorded in the fiscal year ended June 30, 2016.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 20pt; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Income (Loss) Per Share&lt;/b&gt; - Basic&#13;income (loss) per share (EPS) is calculated by dividing the income or loss available to common shareholders by the weighted average&#13;number of common shares outstanding for the period. Diluted EPS reflects the potential dilution that could occur if securities&#13;or other contracts to issue common stock were exercised or converted into common stock. Basic and Diluted EPS were the same for&#13;fiscal 2016 and 2015, as the Company had net losses during both years and therefore the effect of all potential common stock equivalents&#13;is antidilutive (reduces loss per share).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company has a total of 1,340,000&#13;potentially dilutive securities outstanding at June 30, 2016 which includes stock options representing 1,200,000 shares of Class&#13;A Common Stock with exercise prices ranging between $0.50 and $0.75 and 140,000 outstanding stock warrants with exercise prices&#13;ranging between $0.50 and $1.00. At June 30, 2015, the Company had stock options representing 1,203,200 shares of Class A Common&#13;Stock outstanding at June 30, 2015 with exercise prices ranging between $0.50 and $1.50. There were no outstanding warrants as&#13;of June 30, 2015.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Stock Options Plans&lt;/b&gt; - The Company&#13;has stock-based compensation plans. The value of the compensation cost is amortized on a straight-line basis over the requisite&#13;service periods of the award (the option vesting term).&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: -27pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company estimates the fair value&#13;of stock-based awards using the Black-Scholes valuation model. Assumptions used to estimate compensation expense are determined&#13;as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 0.5in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Expected term is determined under the simplified method using an average&#13;of the contractual term and vesting period of the award as appropriate statistical data required to properly estimate the expected&#13;term was not available;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 20pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 0.5in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Expected volatility of award grants made under the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;plans is measured using the historical daily changes in the market price of the Company&amp;#146;s common stock over the expected&#13;term of the award, and contemplation of future activity; &lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 0.5in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Risk-free interest rate is to approximate the implied yield on zero-coupon&#13;U.S. Treasury bonds with a remaining maturity equal to the expected term of the awards; and,&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 20pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: top"&gt;&#13;&lt;td style="width: 0.5in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="width: 0.25in; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font: 8pt Symbol"&gt;&amp;#183;&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;td style="text-align: justify; padding-left: -20pt"&gt;&lt;font style="font-size: 8pt"&gt;Forfeitures are based on the history of cancellations of awards granted&#13;by the Company and management&amp;#146;s analysis of potential forfeitures.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 20pt; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;Concentrations&lt;/b&gt; - The Company&#13;holds cash and cash equivalents in bank accounts that in some cases exceed the maximum FDIC insurance amount. At June 30, 2016&#13;no balances exceeded FDIC insured limits.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Approximately 71.6% of AES revenues&#13;were generated by three customers during the fiscal year 2016 and all three customer accounts were current or paid in full as of&#13;June 30, 2016. During fiscal year 2015, 85.1% of AES revenues were generated by four customers and all amounts billed to those&#13;customers were current or paid in full as of June 30, 2015. The significant customers represented $3,800, or 97.4% of the accounts&#13;receivable balance at June 30, 2016, while the significant customers for fiscal 2015 represented $14,900, or 32.4% of the accounts&#13;receivable balance at June 30, 2015.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&lt;i&gt;Recent Accounting Pronouncements&lt;/i&gt;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In May 2014, the FASB issued guidance&#13;regarding revenue from contracts with customers. The guidance outlines a single comprehensive model for entities to use in accounting&#13;for revenue arising from contracts with customers and supersedes the most current revenue recognition guidance. In August 2015,&#13;this accounting pronouncement was deferred for one year, and is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December&#13;15, 2017, including interim reporting periods within that reporting period. Earlier application is permitted only as of reporting&#13;periods beginning after December 15, 2016. The Company is currently assessing the impact on its financial position and results&#13;of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 10pt Courier New, Courier, Monospace; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: center; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In August 2015, the FASB issued guidance&#13;regarding the presentation and subsequent measurement of debt issuance costs for lines of credit. The guidance allows for the presentation&#13;of debt issuance costs related to line-of-credit agreements as an asset and subsequently amortizing the deferred costs ratably&#13;over the term of the line-of-credit arrangement. The guidance is effective for annual reporting periods beginning after December&#13;15, 2015 and early adoption is permitted. The Company has adopted the guidance, which had no material impact on its financial position&#13;and results of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In January 2016, the FASB issued guidance&#13;regarding the enhancement of reporting financial instruments including aspects of recognition, measurement, presentation and disclosure.&#13;The guidance is effective for periods beginning after December 15, 2017 including interim periods within those fiscal years. While&#13;a portion of the guidance allows for early application, it does not permit complete early adoption. The Company is currently assessing&#13;the impact on its financial position and results of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In February 2016, the FASB issued guidance&#13;regarding lease reporting. The guidance requires a lessee to record on the balance sheet the assets and liabilities for the rights&#13;and obligations created by leases with terms of more than 12 months. The guidance is effective for periods beginning after December&#13;15, 2018 including interim periods within those fiscal years and early adoption is permitted. The Company is currently assessing&#13;the impact on its financial position and results of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In March 2016, the FASB issued guidance&#13;under the simplification initiative regarding stock compensation. The guidance is effective for annual periods beginning after&#13;December 15, 2016 and interim periods within those annual periods. Early adoption is permitted provided that all amendments are&#13;adopted in the same period. The Company is currently assessing the impact on its financial position and results of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In June 2016, the FASB issued guidance&#13;regarding credit losses on financial instruments including loans. The guidance is effective for annual periods beginning after&#13;December 15, 2019 including interim periods within those annual periods. The Company is currently assessing the impact on its financial&#13;position and results of operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;There have been no other recent accounting&#13;pronouncements or changes in accounting pronouncements that are of significance, or potential significance, to us.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:OrganizationConsolidationAndPresentationOfFinancialStatementsDisclosureAndSignificantAccountingPoliciesTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:ShareholdersEquityAndShareBasedPaymentsTextBlock contextRef="From2015-07-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company has several employee stock&#13;option and officer and director stock option plans that have been approved by the shareholders of the Company. The plans require&#13;that options be granted at a price not less than market on the date of grant.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company uses the Black-Scholes&#13;option pricing model to estimate fair value of stock-based awards.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-indent: 0.75pt"&gt;No options were granted during the&#13;year ended June 30, 2016. Assumptions for the award of options granted during the year ended June 30, 2015 were:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-indent: 0.75pt"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-indent: 0.75pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%; border-collapse: collapse; font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif"&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;The Company&amp;#146;s Stock Option Plans are administered&#13;by the Compensation/Administration Committee, currently comprised of two independent members of the Company&amp;#146;s Board of Directors.&#13;Company stock options are issued to employees and directors at an exercise price of not less than the fair market value, as determined&#13;under the option plan on the date of grant and must be granted within 10 years from the effective date of the Plan, with the term&#13;of the option not exceeding 10 years. Options granted to employees under the Stock Option Plans, which are terminated prior to&#13;exercise, are considered to be available for grant to subsequent employees. Total issued stock options for any plan may exceed&#13;those authorized due to termination of prior non-exercised grants. Under the Employee Incentive Stock Option Plans, incentive and&#13;non-qualified stock options may be granted with the incentive stock options intended to qualify under Section 422 of the Internal&#13;Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. Stock options issued during the fiscal year ended June 30, 2015 vested 20% on December 31, 2014&#13;and 20% each quarter thereafter and there were no options issued during the fiscal year ended June 30, 2016.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;table border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="width: 100%;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;-&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;Granted&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;140,000&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;0.75&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="font-weight: bold; text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;20,000&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;0.75&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom;    &lt;td colspan="3"&gt;Warrants Outstanding, June 30, 2016&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;140,000&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;0.75&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: center"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;20,000&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;0.75&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; Refer to Note 7 &amp;#150; Note Payable for more information on the note and detachable warrants.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-indent: 0.75pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:ShareholdersEquityAndShareBasedPaymentsTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:LoansNotesTradeAndOtherReceivablesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2015-07-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Note receivable at June 30, 2016 and&#13;2015 represents a note due from American Citizenship Center, LLC (&amp;#147;ACC&amp;#148;), a related party.    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;(29,000)&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;322,800&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Less long-term&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;(262,800)&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;Notes receivable - current&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;$&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;60,000&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The gross balance of $295,400 at&#13;June 30, 2016 represents the outstanding amount drawn by ACC on a $295,400 credit line provided by the Company at June 30, 2016.&#13;The note is secured by all assets of ACC and at June 30, 2016 bears interest at the rate of 9.5% per annum. At June 30, 2016, ACC&#13;owed the company approximately $2,800 consisting of interest of $2,300 plus $500 of legal fees associated with a note modification&#13;which was paid subsequent to year end. The note was modified twice during the fiscal year 2016 including a modification in January&#13;2016 which deferred minimum principal payments of $10,000 to August 31, 2016.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;ACC&amp;#146;s business plan is based&#13;on the Executive Action, known as DAPA, issued by President Obama in November 2014. The action is designed to expand the original&#13;deferred action program to eligible parents and spouses of U.S. citizens and agricultural workers with a demonstrated history.&#13;In February 2015, twenty-six states filed a lawsuit to stop the program and the court granted an injunction meaning that the U.S.&#13;Government cannot proceed with rolling out the program. The U.S. government appealed the lawsuit which went to the 5&lt;sup&gt;th&lt;/sup&gt;&#13;Circuit Court of Appeals. The appeal was unsuccessful and in January 2016, the Supreme Court granted an oral hearing which was&#13;held in April 2016. In June 2016, the Supreme Court announced that the justice votes were even for and against the DAPA case, effectively&#13;a no decision. As a result, it is presumed that the case will go back to trial at the District Court in Texas. As of June 30, 2016,&#13;the Company has fully reserved for the amount of the note. The required interest payments are current.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;In August 2016, ACC and the Company&#13;again modified the loan agreement by requiring minimum monthly payments of $10,000 per month starting 60 days following implementation&#13;of an immigration reform program which allows DAPA or a similar program to be implemented in the United States. In addition, the&#13;maturity date was extended to August 31, 2018. All other terms of the note remained the same.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:LoansNotesTradeAndOtherReceivablesDisclosureTextBlock>
    <ALAN:AlancoEnergyServicesDisclosureTextBlock contextRef="From2015-07-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During fiscal 2012, the Company formed&#13;Alanco Energy Services, Inc. (&amp;#147;AES&amp;#148;), a wholly-owned subsidiary, and in April 2012 executed an agreement with TC Operating,&#13;LLC (&amp;#34;TCO&amp;#34;) of Grand Junction, CO to transfer a land lease for approximately 24 acres near Grand Junction, CO and all&#13;related assets to AES with the intent for AES to construct facilities for the treatment and disposal of large quantities of produced&#13;water generated by oil and natural gas producers in Western Colorado. The site was chosen due to its unique ability to meet stringent&#13;government requirements for disposal of the high saline water produced as a by-product of oil and gas production, and termed &amp;#34;produced&#13;water&amp;#34;. The agreement included the transfer of all related tangible and intangible assets as well as Federal, State and County&#13;permits (issued or in process) required to construct the facilities. The lease terms payable to the landlord include a minimum&#13;monthly lease payment of $100 per acre ($2,400 per month) during the initial ten year term of the lease, plus approximately $0.25&#13;per barrel of produced water received at the site.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;The design and construction of the&#13;Deer Creek water disposal facility required certain changes to the Goodwin Solid Waste facility (&amp;#147;Goodwin&amp;#148;) resulting&#13;in extra costs to the landlord, who also owned Goodwin. As incentive for the landlord to approve the facility design, AES agreed&#13;to limit landlord construction improvement costs related to the leased land to $200,000. Included in the $200,000 limited amount&#13;was $100,000 of landlord improvement costs to be paid by AES and reimbursed through a 50% credit against the $0.25 per barrel royalty&#13;payments due landlord discussed above. AES recorded the $100,000 payment as prepaid royalties which expired on August 31, 2015&#13;under terms of the agreement and therefore had a zero balance at June 30, 2016. The prepaid balance June 30, 2015 was $5,100.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -20pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;TCO can also earn additional purchase&#13;price payments based upon a percentage of the net cumulative EBITDA (net of all related AES capital investments) over a period&#13;of approximately 10 years (contingent purchase price), approximately the initial term of the lease. As of June 30, 2016 and 2015,&#13;the Company had no liability recorded for the contingent purchase price based on the probability of the contingent payment being&#13;realized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During April 2012, AES also entered&#13;into a definitive agreement with Deer Creek Disposal, LLC (&amp;#34;DCD&amp;#34;) whereby AES acquired a 160 acre site near Grand Junction,&#13;CO, for additional expansion to the proposed water treatment and disposal facility. As consideration for the land purchase, AES&#13;paid $500,000 at the April 13, 2012 closing and assumed a non-interest bearing, secured, $200,000 note due November 15, 2012, which&#13;was repaid upon maturity. AES has also agreed to potential additional quarterly earn-out payments to DCD up to a maximum total&#13;of $800,000, generally determined as 10% of quarterly revenues in excess of operating expenses up to $200,000 per quarter (contingent&#13;land payment). See Note 8 - Contingent Payments for additional discussion of the contingent land payment. The land, known as Indian&#13;Mesa, is currently undeveloped. In June 2014 AES received final construction approval from the Colorado Department of Public Health&#13;and Environment (CDPHE) for twelve produced water disposal ponds. During fiscal year 2016, the Company implemented a plan to divest&#13;the undeveloped Indian Mesa facility. See Note 5 &amp;#150; Assets Held for Sale for additional discussion.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: center"&gt;&lt;b&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/b&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;Related to the treatment and disposal&#13;facilities, in fiscal year 2012 AES entered into a management agreement with TCO to manage the project for a monthly management&#13;fee of $10,000 initially and $20,000 after final permits for the Deer Creek operation were obtained in May 2012. The management&#13;agreement expired in January 2013 and continued on a month to month basis through March 31, 2015, at which time the Company elected&#13;not to continue the month to month arrangement. Effective April 1, 2015, the Company entered into an agreement for operations&#13;management services for the Deer Creek facility with a separate management company. The agreement is cancellable by either party&#13;at any time and was cancelled by the Company subsequent to year end. &lt;font style="font-weight: normal; font-style: normal; text-transform: none; letter-spacing: normal; word-spacing: 0px; background-color: rgb(255, 255, 255)"&gt;The&#13;Company continues to have one employee who is responsible for accepting deliveries at the site.&lt;/font&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</ALAN:AlancoEnergyServicesDisclosureTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:DisclosureOfLongLivedAssetsHeldForSaleTextBlock contextRef="From2015-07-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;During the fiscal year 2016, Alanco&amp;#146;s&#13;Board of Directors approved a formal plan to sell its 160 acre owned and undeveloped land and associated permits known as Indian&#13;Mesa. The plan was contemplated because the Company is expanding into other markets that are unrelated to waste disposal. The Company&#13;is utilizing the services of an investment banker to represent the Company in the sale of these assets and expects the sale to&#13;occur within one year. Accordingly, the Assets Held for Sale of $1,653,500 presented in the attached balance sheet as of June 30,&#13;2016 represents the Indian Mesa land and associated permits. The reclassification of the assets to Assets Held for Sale does not&#13;affect the Consolidated Statements of Operations as the Indian Mesa land is undeveloped and has no associated operations.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:DisclosureOfLongLivedAssetsHeldForSaleTextBlock>

As a result, the value of those&#13;assets has been reclassified to Assets Held for Sale as of June 30, 2016.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 27pt; text-align: justify"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:PropertyPlantAndEquipmentDisclosureTextBlock>

   &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="margin-top: 0; margin-bottom: 0"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;At June 30, 2016, the Note Payable&#13;balance of $200,000 represents the amount drawn against a $500,000 line of credit with the Anderson Family Trust (&amp;#147;Trust&amp;#148;)&#13;entered into on June 28, 2016. As of June 30, 2016, the line of credit has an available balance of $300,000. The line of credit&#13;matures on July 1, 2017 when the full outstanding balance is due. The balance accrues interest at 7% per annum payable monthly&#13;and is collateralized by the Company&amp;#146;s AES Indian Mesa property. In addition, the Trust was paid a loan fee of $10,000 plus&#13;a warrant to purchase 140,000 shares of Alanco Common Stock of which 20,000 warrants vested immediately and 10,000 warrants vest&#13;monthly. The exercise price per share for the warrants is $0.50 per share for one half of each vested group and $1.00 for the other&#13;half of each vested group with a five year term following the issuance date. The Company uses the Black-Scholes option pricing&#13;model to estimate fair value of stock-based awards.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 12pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-indent: 0.5in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-indent: 0.75pt"&gt;Assumptions for warrants granted during&#13;the year ended June 30, 2016 were:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; The line of credit has&#13;a provision allowing the lender, at the lender&amp;#146;s option, to convert up to the full amount of the credit line into shares&#13;of a then available class of preferred stock outstanding any time prior to the full repayment of the line of credit.     <us-gaap:LegalMattersAndContingenciesTextBlock contextRef="From2015-07-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;Contingent&#13;payments at June 30, 2016 and 2015 are as follows:&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;653,900&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;Less current portion&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;-&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;(50,000)&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;tr style="vertical-align: bottom; background-color: white"&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;Contingent payments, long-term&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;672,700&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="border-top: Black 0.5pt solid; border-bottom: Black 2pt double; text-align: right"&gt;603,900&lt;/td&gt;&lt;/tr&gt;&#13;&lt;/table&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;Contingent&#13;land payment represents the net present value of $800,000 of contingent land payments due under an agreement whereby Alanco Energy&#13;Services, Inc. (&amp;#147;AES&amp;#148;) acquired 160 acres of land known as Indian Mesa. The maximum total of $800,000 of contingent&#13;land payments is based upon 10% of quarterly revenues in excess of operating expenses up to $200,000 per quarter for activity at&#13;both the Deer Creek and the Indian Mesa locations. The payments were projected considering operating plans as approved by the Alanco&#13;Board of Directors, with the payments discounted at a rate of 3% per annum. During the fiscal year ended June 30, 2016 no contingent&#13;land payments were made while $8,600 was paid in fiscal year 2015. The Company will maintain the liability for contingent payments&#13;resulting from future revenues on the Indian Mesa land resulting from an eventual buyer&amp;#146;s operations. See Note 4 &amp;#150;&#13;Alanco Energy Services for additional discussion on AES operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify"&gt;TCO can also earn additional purchase&#13;price payments based upon a percentage of the net cumulative EBITDA (net of all related AES capital investments) over a period&#13;of approximately 10 years (contingent purchase price), approximately the initial term of the lease. As of June 30, 2016 and 2015,&#13;the Company had no liability recorded for the contingent purchase price based on the probability of the contingent payment being&#13;realized.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The significant&#13;unobservable inputs used in the fair value measurement of the Company&amp;#146;s fair value calculation for the contingent land payment&#13;and contingent purchase price include cash flow projections, the probability of the contingent payments being realized, the timing&#13;of when the payments are paid and the discount rate applied. Significant changes in any of those inputs in isolation would result&#13;in a significantly different fair value measurement. See Note 4 &amp;#150; Alanco Energy Services for additional discussion on AES&#13;operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 -40pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:LegalMattersAndContingenciesTextBlock>
    <us-gaap:AssetRetirementObligationsAndEnvironmentalCostPolicyTextBlock contextRef="From2015-07-01to2016-06-30">&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The Company&#13;initially recognized an estimated asset retirement obligation (closure cost) at June 30, 2012 of $410,000 to remove leasehold improvements,&#13;remediate any pollution issues and return the Deer Creek water disposal property to its natural state at the conclusion of the&#13;Company&amp;#146;s lease. The closure process is a requirement of both the Deer Creek lease and the State of Colorado, a permitting&#13;authority for such facilities. The initial closure cost estimate, in then current dollars, was completed by an approved independent&#13;consultant experienced in estimating closure costs for water disposal operations and the estimated amount was approved by the State&#13;of Colorado.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 20pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: -0.25in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The Company&#13;reviews the contingent asset retirement obligation on a recurring basis and records changes in the period incurred. At June 30,&#13;2016, the estimated closure costs were again reviewed and the only adjustment was a 1.01% inflation adjustment as required under&#13;agreement with the Colorado Department of Public Health and Environment, increasing the asset retirement obligation to $434,000,&#13;AES&amp;#146;s approximate 75% share of the $566,000 estimated closure costs for both the Deer Creek facility and the adjacent Goodwin&#13;Solid Waste facility (Goodwin is not owned by AES). At June 30, 2015, the only adjustment was a 1.014% inflation adjustment, increasing&#13;the asset retirement obligation to $429,700. The significant unobservable inputs used in the fair value measurement of the Company&amp;#146;s&#13;fair value calculation for the asset retirement obligation include the estimated cost to close the Deer Creek facility in accordance&#13;with state approved closure plans. Significant changes in any of those inputs in isolation would result in a significantly different&#13;fair value measurement. See Note 4 &amp;#150; Alanco Energy Services for additional discussion on AES operations.&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;&amp;#160;&lt;/p&gt;&#13;&#13;&lt;p style="font: 8pt/normal Times New Roman, Times, Serif; margin: 0 0 0 0pt; text-align: justify; text-indent: 0in"&gt;The laws of&#13;the State of Colorado require companies to meet environmental and asset retirement obligations by selecting an approved payment&#13;method. The Company has elected to meet its obligation by making an initial payment of approximately $25,300 and quarterly payments&#13;of approximately $4,700 into a trust that over the expected lease period will build liquid assets to meet the asset retirement&#13;obligation. For the fiscal years ended June 30, 2016 and 2015, the trust account balance was $86,100 and $67,400, respectively.&lt;/p&gt;</us-gaap:AssetRetirementObligationsAndEnvironmentalCostPolicyTextBlock>

   &lt;td&gt;Deferred tax asset&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;$&lt;/td&gt;&#13;    &lt;td style="text-align: right"&gt;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;&amp;#160;12,100,000&lt;/td&gt;&#13;
